title: Lecture Notes: Optimization for Machine Learning
chunk_text:
Lecture notes on optimization for machine learning, derived from a course at
Princeton University and tutorials given in MLSS, Buenos Aires, as well as
Simons Foundation, Berkeley.

title: An Optimal Control View of Adversarial Machine Learning
chunk_text:
I describe an optimal control view of adversarial machine learning, where the
dynamical system is the machine learner, the input are adversarial actions, and
the control costs are defined by the adversary's goals to do harm and be hard
to detect.

title: An Optimal Control View of Adversarial Machine Learning
chunk_text:
This view encompasses many types of adversarial machine learning,
including test-item attacks, training-data poisoning, and adversarial reward
shaping.

title: An Optimal Control View of Adversarial Machine Learning
chunk_text:
The view encourages adversarial machine learning researcher to utilize
advances in control theory and reinforcement learning.

title:
Minimax deviation strategies for machine learning and recognition with
  short learning samples
chunk_text:
The article is devoted to the problem of small learning samples in machine
learning.

title:
Minimax deviation strategies for machine learning and recognition with
  short learning samples
chunk_text:
The flaws of maximum likelihood learning and minimax learning are
looked into and the concept of minimax deviation learning is introduced that is
free of those flaws.

title: Machine Learning for Clinical Predictive Analytics
chunk_text:
In this chapter, we provide a brief overview of applying machine learning
techniques for clinical prediction tasks.

title: Machine Learning for Clinical Predictive Analytics
chunk_text:
We begin with a quick introduction to
the concepts of machine learning and outline some of the most common machine
learning algorithms.

title: Machine Learning for Clinical Predictive Analytics
chunk_text:
Next, we demonstrate how to apply the algorithms with
appropriate toolkits to conduct machine learning experiments for clinical
prediction tasks.

title: Machine Learning for Clinical Predictive Analytics
chunk_text:
The objectives of this chapter are to (1) understand the
basics of machine learning techniques and the reasons behind why they are
useful for solving clinical prediction problems, (2) understand the intuition
behind some machine learning models, including regression, decision trees, and
support vector machines, and (3) understand how to apply these models to
clinical prediction problems using publicly available datasets via case
studies.

title:
Towards Modular Machine Learning Solution Development: Benefits and
  Trade-offs
chunk_text:
Machine learning technologies have demonstrated immense capabilities in
various domains. They play a key role in the success of modern businesses.

title:
Towards Modular Machine Learning Solution Development: Benefits and
  Trade-offs
chunk_text:
However, adoption of machine learning technologies has a lot of untouched
potential.

title:
Towards Modular Machine Learning Solution Development: Benefits and
  Trade-offs
chunk_text:
Cost of developing custom machine learning solutions that solve
unique business problems is a major inhibitor to far-reaching adoption of
machine learning technologies.

title:
Towards Modular Machine Learning Solution Development: Benefits and
  Trade-offs
chunk_text:
We recognize that the monolithic nature
prevalent in today's machine learning applications stands in the way of
efficient and cost effective customized machine learning solution development.

title:
Towards Modular Machine Learning Solution Development: Benefits and
  Trade-offs
chunk_text:
In this work we explore the benefits of modular machine learning solutions and
discuss how modular machine learning solutions can overcome some of the major
solution engineering limitations of monolithic machine learning solutions.

title:
Towards Modular Machine Learning Solution Development: Benefits and
  Trade-offs
chunk_text:
We
analyze the trade-offs between modular and monolithic machine learning
solutions through three deep learning problems; one text based and the two
image based.

title:
Towards Modular Machine Learning Solution Development: Benefits and
  Trade-offs
chunk_text:
Our experimental results show that modular machine learning
solutions have a promising potential to reap the solution engineering
advantages of modularity while gaining performance and data advantages in a way
the monolithic machine learning solutions do not permit.

title: Introduction to Machine Learning: Class Notes 67577
chunk_text:
Introduction to Machine learning covering Statistical Inference (Bayes, EM,
ML/MaxEnt duality), algebraic and spectral methods (PCA, LDA, CCA, Clustering),
and PAC learning (the Formal model, VC dimension, Double Sampling theorem).

title: The Tribes of Machine Learning and the Realm of Computer Architecture
chunk_text:
Machine learning techniques have influenced the field of computer
architecture like many other fields.

title: The Tribes of Machine Learning and the Realm of Computer Architecture
chunk_text:
This paper studies how the fundamental
machine learning techniques can be applied towards computer architecture
problems.

title: The Tribes of Machine Learning and the Realm of Computer Architecture
chunk_text:
We also provide a detailed survey of computer architecture research
that employs different machine learning methods.

title: The Tribes of Machine Learning and the Realm of Computer Architecture
chunk_text:
Finally, we present some
future opportunities and the outstanding challenges that need to be overcome to
exploit full potential of machine learning for computer architecture.

title:
A Machine Learning Tutorial for Operational Meteorology, Part I:
  Traditional Machine Learning
chunk_text: Recently, the use of machine learning in meteorology has increased greatly.

title:
A Machine Learning Tutorial for Operational Meteorology, Part I:
  Traditional Machine Learning
chunk_text:
While many machine learning methods are not new, university classes on machine
learning are largely unavailable to meteorology students and are not required
to become a meteorologist.

title:
A Machine Learning Tutorial for Operational Meteorology, Part I:
  Traditional Machine Learning
chunk_text:
The lack of formal instruction has contributed to
perception that machine learning methods are 'black boxes' and thus end-users
are hesitant to apply the machine learning methods in their every day workflow.

title:
A Machine Learning Tutorial for Operational Meteorology, Part I:
  Traditional Machine Learning
chunk_text:
To reduce the opaqueness of machine learning methods and lower hesitancy
towards machine learning in meteorology, this paper provides a survey of some
of the most common machine learning methods.

title:
A Machine Learning Tutorial for Operational Meteorology, Part I:
  Traditional Machine Learning
chunk_text:
A familiar meteorological example
is used to contextualize the machine learning methods while also discussing
machine learning topics using plain language.

title:
A Machine Learning Tutorial for Operational Meteorology, Part I:
  Traditional Machine Learning
chunk_text:
The following machine learning
methods are demonstrated: linear regression; logistic regression; decision
trees; random forest; gradient boosted decision trees; naive Bayes; and support
vector machines.

title:
A Machine Learning Tutorial for Operational Meteorology, Part I:
  Traditional Machine Learning
chunk_text:
Beyond discussing the different methods, the paper also
contains discussions on the general machine learning process as well as best
practices to enable readers to apply machine learning to their own datasets.

title:
A Machine Learning Tutorial for Operational Meteorology, Part I:
  Traditional Machine Learning
chunk_text:
Furthermore, all code (in the form of Jupyter notebooks and Google Colaboratory
notebooks) used to make the examples in the paper is provided in an effort to
catalyse the use of machine learning in meteorology.

title: Position Paper: Towards Transparent Machine Learning
chunk_text:
Transparent machine learning is introduced as an alternative form of machine
learning, where both the model and the learning system are represented in
source code form.

title: Position Paper: Towards Transparent Machine Learning
chunk_text:
The goal of this project is to enable direct human
understanding of machine learning models, giving us the ability to learn,
verify, and refine them as programs.

title: Position Paper: Towards Transparent Machine Learning
chunk_text:
If solved, this technology could represent
a best-case scenario for the safety and security of AI systems going forward.

title: Understanding Bias in Machine Learning
chunk_text:
Bias is known to be an impediment to fair decisions in many domains such as
human resources, the public sector, health care etc.

title: Understanding Bias in Machine Learning
chunk_text:
Recently, hope has been
expressed that the use of machine learning methods for taking such decisions
would diminish or even resolve the problem.

title: Understanding Bias in Machine Learning
chunk_text:
At the same time, machine learning
experts warn that machine learning models can be biased as well.

title: Understanding Bias in Machine Learning
chunk_text:
In this
article, our goal is to explain the issue of bias in machine learning from a
technical perspective and to illustrate the impact that biased data can have on
a machine learning model.

title: Understanding Bias in Machine Learning
chunk_text:
To reach such a goal, we develop interactive plots to
visualizing the bias learned from synthetic data.

title:
A Unified Analytical Framework for Trustable Machine Learning and
  Automation Running with Blockchain
chunk_text:
Traditional machine learning algorithms use data from databases that are
mutable, and therefore the data cannot be fully trusted. Also, the machine
learning process is difficult to automate.

title:
A Unified Analytical Framework for Trustable Machine Learning and
  Automation Running with Blockchain
chunk_text:
This paper proposes building a
trustable machine learning system by using blockchain technology, which can
store data in a permanent and immutable way.

title:
A Unified Analytical Framework for Trustable Machine Learning and
  Automation Running with Blockchain
chunk_text:
In addition, smart contracts are
used to automate the machine learning process. This paper makes three
contributions.

title:
A Unified Analytical Framework for Trustable Machine Learning and
  Automation Running with Blockchain
chunk_text:
First, it establishes a link between machine learning technology
and blockchain technology.

title:
A Unified Analytical Framework for Trustable Machine Learning and
  Automation Running with Blockchain
chunk_text:
Previously, machine learning and blockchain have
been considered two independent technologies without an obvious link.

title:
A Unified Analytical Framework for Trustable Machine Learning and
  Automation Running with Blockchain
chunk_text:
Second,
it proposes a unified analytical framework for trustable machine learning by
using blockchain technology.

title:
A Unified Analytical Framework for Trustable Machine Learning and
  Automation Running with Blockchain
chunk_text:
This unified framework solves both the
trustability and automation issues in machine learning.

title:
A Unified Analytical Framework for Trustable Machine Learning and
  Automation Running with Blockchain
chunk_text:
Third, it enables a
computer to translate core machine learning implementation from a single thread
on a single machine to multiple threads on multiple machines running with
blockchain by using a unified approach.

title:
A Unified Analytical Framework for Trustable Machine Learning and
  Automation Running with Blockchain
chunk_text:
The paper uses association rule mining
as an example to demonstrate how trustable machine learning can be implemented
with blockchain, and it shows how this approach can be used to analyze opioid
prescriptions to help combat the opioid crisis.

title:
MLBench: How Good Are Machine Learning Clouds for Binary Classification
  Tasks on Structured Data?
chunk_text:
We conduct an empirical study of machine learning functionalities provided by
major cloud service providers, which we call machine learning clouds.

title:
MLBench: How Good Are Machine Learning Clouds for Binary Classification
  Tasks on Structured Data?
chunk_text:
Machine
learning clouds hold the promise of hiding all the sophistication of running
large-scale machine learning: Instead of specifying how to run a machine
learning task, users only specify what machine learning task to run and the
cloud figures out the rest.

title:
MLBench: How Good Are Machine Learning Clouds for Binary Classification
  Tasks on Structured Data?
chunk_text:
Raising the level of abstraction, however, rarely
comes free - a performance penalty is possible. How good, then, are current
machine learning clouds on real-world machine learning workloads?

title:
MLBench: How Good Are Machine Learning Clouds for Binary Classification
  Tasks on Structured Data?
chunk_text:
We study this question with a focus on binary classication problems. We
present mlbench, a novel benchmark constructed by harvesting datasets from
Kaggle competitions.

title:
MLBench: How Good Are Machine Learning Clouds for Binary Classification
  Tasks on Structured Data?
chunk_text:
We then compare the performance of the top winning code
available from Kaggle with that of running machine learning clouds from both
Azure and Amazon on mlbench.

title:
MLBench: How Good Are Machine Learning Clouds for Binary Classification
  Tasks on Structured Data?
chunk_text:
Our comparative study reveals the strength and
weakness of existing machine learning clouds and points out potential future
directions for improvement.

title: Data Pricing in Machine Learning Pipelines
chunk_text: Machine learning is disruptive.

title: Data Pricing in Machine Learning Pipelines
chunk_text:
At the same time, machine learning can only
succeed by collaboration among many parties in multiple steps naturally as
pipelines in an eco-system, such as collecting data for possible machine
learning applications, collaboratively training models by multiple parties and
delivering machine learning services to end users.

title: Data Pricing in Machine Learning Pipelines
chunk_text:
Data is critical and
penetrating in the whole machine learning pipelines.

title: Data Pricing in Machine Learning Pipelines
chunk_text:
As machine learning
pipelines involve many parties and, in order to be successful, have to form a
constructive and dynamic eco-system, marketplaces and data pricing are
fundamental in connecting and facilitating those many parties.

title: Data Pricing in Machine Learning Pipelines
chunk_text:
In this article,
we survey the principles and the latest research development of data pricing in
machine learning pipelines. We start with a brief review of data marketplaces
and pricing desiderata.

title: Data Pricing in Machine Learning Pipelines
chunk_text:
Then, we focus on pricing in three important steps in
machine learning pipelines. To understand pricing in the step of training data
collection, we review pricing raw data sets and data labels.

title: Data Pricing in Machine Learning Pipelines
chunk_text:
We also
investigate pricing in the step of collaborative training of machine learning
models, and overview pricing machine learning models for end users in the step
of machine learning deployment.

title: Data Pricing in Machine Learning Pipelines
chunk_text:
We also discuss a series of possible future
directions.

title: Techniques for Automated Machine Learning
chunk_text:
Automated machine learning (AutoML) aims to find optimal machine learning
solutions automatically given a machine learning problem.

title: Techniques for Automated Machine Learning
chunk_text:
It could release the
burden of data scientists from the multifarious manual tuning process and
enable the access of domain experts to the off-the-shelf machine learning
solutions without extensive experience.

title: Techniques for Automated Machine Learning
chunk_text:
In this paper, we review the current
developments of AutoML in terms of three categories, automated feature
engineering (AutoFE), automated model and hyperparameter learning (AutoMHL),
and automated deep learning (AutoDL).

title: Techniques for Automated Machine Learning
chunk_text:
State-of-the-art techniques adopted in
the three categories are presented, including Bayesian optimization,
reinforcement learning, evolutionary algorithm, and gradient-based approaches.

title: Techniques for Automated Machine Learning
chunk_text:
We summarize popular AutoML frameworks and conclude with current open
challenges of AutoML.

title:
The Landscape of Modern Machine Learning: A Review of Machine,
  Distributed and Federated Learning
chunk_text:
With the advance of the powerful heterogeneous, parallel and distributed
computing systems and ever increasing immense amount of data, machine learning
has become an indispensable part of cutting-edge technology, scientific
research and consumer products.

title:
The Landscape of Modern Machine Learning: A Review of Machine,
  Distributed and Federated Learning
chunk_text:
In this study, we present a review of modern
machine and deep learning. We provide a high-level overview for the latest
advanced machine learning algorithms, applications, and frameworks.

title:
The Landscape of Modern Machine Learning: A Review of Machine,
  Distributed and Federated Learning
chunk_text:
Our
discussion encompasses parallel distributed learning, deep learning as well as
federated learning. As a result, our work serves as an introductory text to the
vast field of modern machine learning.

title:
Parallelization of Machine Learning Algorithms Respectively on Single
  Machine and Spark
chunk_text:
With the rapid development of big data technologies, how to dig out useful
information from massive data becomes an essential problem.

title:
Parallelization of Machine Learning Algorithms Respectively on Single
  Machine and Spark
chunk_text:
However, using
machine learning algorithms to analyze large data may be time-consuming and
inefficient on the traditional single machine.

title:
Parallelization of Machine Learning Algorithms Respectively on Single
  Machine and Spark
chunk_text:
To solve these problems, this
paper has made some research on the parallelization of several classic machine
learning algorithms respectively on the single machine and the big data
platform Spark.

title:
Parallelization of Machine Learning Algorithms Respectively on Single
  Machine and Spark
chunk_text:
We compare the runtime and efficiency of traditional machine
learning algorithms with parallelized machine learning algorithms respectively
on the single machine and Spark platform.

title:
Parallelization of Machine Learning Algorithms Respectively on Single
  Machine and Spark
chunk_text:
The research results have shown
significant improvement in runtime and efficiency of parallelized machine
learning algorithms.

title: AutoCompete: A Framework for Machine Learning Competition
chunk_text:
In this paper, we propose AutoCompete, a highly automated machine learning
framework for tackling machine learning competitions.

title: AutoCompete: A Framework for Machine Learning Competition
chunk_text:
This framework has been
learned by us, validated and improved over a period of more than two years by
participating in online machine learning competitions.

title: AutoCompete: A Framework for Machine Learning Competition
chunk_text:
It aims at minimizing
human interference required to build a first useful predictive model and to
assess the practical difficulty of a given machine learning challenge.

title: AutoCompete: A Framework for Machine Learning Competition
chunk_text:
The
proposed system helps in identifying data types, choosing a machine learn- ing
model, tuning hyper-parameters, avoiding over-fitting and optimization for a
provided evaluation metric.

title: AutoCompete: A Framework for Machine Learning Competition
chunk_text:
We also observe that the proposed system produces
better (or comparable) results with less runtime as compared to other
approaches.

title: Joint Training of Deep Boltzmann Machines
chunk_text: We introduce a new method for training deep Boltzmann machines jointly.

title: Joint Training of Deep Boltzmann Machines
chunk_text:
Prior
methods require an initial learning pass that trains the deep Boltzmann machine
greedily, one layer at a time, or do not perform well on classifi- cation
tasks.

title:
Proceedings of the 2016 ICML Workshop on #Data4Good: Machine Learning in
  Social Good Applications
chunk_text:
This is the Proceedings of the ICML Workshop on #Data4Good: Machine Learning
in Social Good Applications, which was held on June 24, 2016 in New York.

title: Mathematical Perspective of Machine Learning
chunk_text:
We take a closer look at some theoretical challenges of Machine Learning as a
function approximation, gradient descent as the default optimization algorithm,
limitations of fixed length and width networks and a different approach to RNNs
from a mathematical perspective.

title: Private Machine Learning via Randomised Response
chunk_text:
We introduce a general learning framework for private machine learning based
on randomised response.

title: Private Machine Learning via Randomised Response
chunk_text:
Our assumption is that all actors are potentially
adversarial and as such we trust only to release a single noisy version of an
individual's datapoint.

title: Private Machine Learning via Randomised Response
chunk_text:
We discuss a general approach that forms a consistent
way to estimate the true underlying machine learning model and demonstrate this
in the case of logistic regression.

title: Ten-year Survival Prediction for Breast Cancer Patients
chunk_text:
This report assesses different machine learning approaches to 10-year
survival prediction of breast cancer patients.

title: A Survey of Optimization Methods from a Machine Learning Perspective
chunk_text:
Machine learning develops rapidly, which has made many theoretical
breakthroughs and is widely applied in various fields.

title: A Survey of Optimization Methods from a Machine Learning Perspective
chunk_text:
Optimization, as an
important part of machine learning, has attracted much attention of
researchers.

title: A Survey of Optimization Methods from a Machine Learning Perspective
chunk_text:
With the exponential growth of data amount and the increase of
model complexity, optimization methods in machine learning face more and more
challenges.

title: A Survey of Optimization Methods from a Machine Learning Perspective
chunk_text:
A lot of work on solving optimization problems or improving
optimization methods in machine learning has been proposed successively.

title: A Survey of Optimization Methods from a Machine Learning Perspective
chunk_text:
The
systematic retrospect and summary of the optimization methods from the
perspective of machine learning are of great significance, which can offer
guidance for both developments of optimization and machine learning research.

title: A Survey of Optimization Methods from a Machine Learning Perspective
chunk_text:
In this paper, we first describe the optimization problems in machine learning. Then, we introduce the principles and progresses of commonly used optimization
methods.

title: A Survey of Optimization Methods from a Machine Learning Perspective
chunk_text:
Next, we summarize the applications and developments of optimization
methods in some popular machine learning fields.

title: A Survey of Optimization Methods from a Machine Learning Perspective
chunk_text:
Finally, we explore and give
some challenges and open problems for the optimization in machine learning.

title: Tuning Learning Rates with the Cumulative-Learning Constant
chunk_text:
This paper introduces a novel method for optimizing learning rates in machine
learning.

title: Tuning Learning Rates with the Cumulative-Learning Constant
chunk_text:
A previously unrecognized proportionality between learning rates and
dataset sizes is discovered, providing valuable insights into how dataset scale
influences training dynamics.

title: Tuning Learning Rates with the Cumulative-Learning Constant
chunk_text:
Additionally, a cumulative learning constant is
identified, offering a framework for designing and optimizing advanced learning
rate schedules.

title: Tuning Learning Rates with the Cumulative-Learning Constant
chunk_text:
These findings have the potential to enhance training
efficiency and performance across a wide range of machine learning
applications.

title: When Machine Learning Meets Privacy: A Survey and Outlook
chunk_text: The newly emerged machine learning (e.g.

title: When Machine Learning Meets Privacy: A Survey and Outlook
chunk_text:
deep learning) methods have become a
strong driving force to revolutionize a wide range of industries, such as smart
healthcare, financial technology, and surveillance systems.

title: When Machine Learning Meets Privacy: A Survey and Outlook
chunk_text:
Meanwhile, privacy
has emerged as a big concern in this machine learning-based artificial
intelligence era.

title: When Machine Learning Meets Privacy: A Survey and Outlook
chunk_text:
It is important to note that the problem of privacy
preservation in the context of machine learning is quite different from that in
traditional data privacy protection, as machine learning can act as both friend
and foe.

title: When Machine Learning Meets Privacy: A Survey and Outlook
chunk_text:
Currently, the work on the preservation of privacy and machine
learning (ML) is still in an infancy stage, as most existing solutions only
focus on privacy problems during the machine learning process.

title: When Machine Learning Meets Privacy: A Survey and Outlook
chunk_text:
Therefore, a
comprehensive study on the privacy preservation problems and machine learning
is required. This paper surveys the state of the art in privacy issues and
solutions for machine learning.

title: When Machine Learning Meets Privacy: A Survey and Outlook
chunk_text:
The survey covers three categories of
interactions between privacy and machine learning: (i) private machine
learning, (ii) machine learning aided privacy protection, and (iii) machine
learning-based privacy attack and corresponding protection schemes.

title: When Machine Learning Meets Privacy: A Survey and Outlook
chunk_text:
The current
research progress in each category is reviewed and the key challenges are
identified.

title: When Machine Learning Meets Privacy: A Survey and Outlook
chunk_text:
Finally, based on our in-depth analysis of the area of privacy and
machine learning, we point out future research directions in this field.

title: Probabilistic Machine Learning for Healthcare
chunk_text:
Machine learning can be used to make sense of healthcare data. Probabilistic
machine learning models help provide a complete picture of observed data in
healthcare.

title: Probabilistic Machine Learning for Healthcare
chunk_text:
In this review, we examine how probabilistic machine learning can
advance healthcare.

title: Probabilistic Machine Learning for Healthcare
chunk_text:
We consider challenges in the predictive model building
pipeline where probabilistic models can be beneficial including calibration and
missing data.

title: Probabilistic Machine Learning for Healthcare
chunk_text:
Beyond predictive models, we also investigate the utility of
probabilistic machine learning models in phenotyping, in generative models for
clinical use cases, and in reinforcement learning.

title: Evaluation Challenges for Geospatial ML
chunk_text:
As geospatial machine learning models and maps derived from their predictions
are increasingly used for downstream analyses in science and policy, it is
imperative to evaluate their accuracy and applicability.

title: Evaluation Challenges for Geospatial ML
chunk_text:
Geospatial machine
learning has key distinctions from other learning paradigms, and as such, the
correct way to measure performance of spatial machine learning outputs has been
a topic of debate.

title: Evaluation Challenges for Geospatial ML
chunk_text:
In this paper, I delineate unique challenges of model
evaluation for geospatial machine learning with global or remotely sensed
datasets, culminating in concrete takeaways to improve evaluations of
geospatial model performance.

title:
A comprehensive review of Quantum Machine Learning: from NISQ to Fault
  Tolerance
chunk_text:
Quantum machine learning, which involves running machine learning algorithms
on quantum devices, has garnered significant attention in both academic and
business circles.

title:
A comprehensive review of Quantum Machine Learning: from NISQ to Fault
  Tolerance
chunk_text:
In this paper, we offer a comprehensive and unbiased review
of the various concepts that have emerged in the field of quantum machine
learning.

title:
A comprehensive review of Quantum Machine Learning: from NISQ to Fault
  Tolerance
chunk_text:
This includes techniques used in Noisy Intermediate-Scale Quantum
(NISQ) technologies and approaches for algorithms compatible with
fault-tolerant quantum computing hardware.

title:
A comprehensive review of Quantum Machine Learning: from NISQ to Fault
  Tolerance
chunk_text:
Our review covers fundamental
concepts, algorithms, and the statistical learning theory pertinent to quantum
machine learning.

title: Augmented Q Imitation Learning (AQIL)
chunk_text:
The study of unsupervised learning can be generally divided into two
categories: imitation learning and reinforcement learning.

title: Augmented Q Imitation Learning (AQIL)
chunk_text:
In imitation
learning the machine learns by mimicking the behavior of an expert system
whereas in reinforcement learning the machine learns via direct environment
feedback.

title: Augmented Q Imitation Learning (AQIL)
chunk_text:
Traditional deep reinforcement learning takes a significant time
before the machine starts to converge to an optimal policy.

title: Augmented Q Imitation Learning (AQIL)
chunk_text:
This paper proposes
Augmented Q-Imitation-Learning, a method by which deep reinforcement learning
convergence can be accelerated by applying Q-imitation-learning as the initial
training process in traditional Deep Q-learning.

title:
Towards CRISP-ML(Q): A Machine Learning Process Model with Quality
  Assurance Methodology
chunk_text:
Machine learning is an established and frequently used technique in industry
and academia but a standard process model to improve success and efficiency of
machine learning applications is still missing.

title:
Towards CRISP-ML(Q): A Machine Learning Process Model with Quality
  Assurance Methodology
chunk_text:
Project organizations and
machine learning practitioners have a need for guidance throughout the life
cycle of a machine learning application to meet business expectations.

title:
Towards CRISP-ML(Q): A Machine Learning Process Model with Quality
  Assurance Methodology
chunk_text:
We
therefore propose a process model for the development of machine learning
applications, that covers six phases from defining the scope to maintaining the
deployed machine learning application.

title:
Towards CRISP-ML(Q): A Machine Learning Process Model with Quality
  Assurance Methodology
chunk_text:
The first phase combines business and
data understanding as data availability oftentimes affects the feasibility of
the project.

title:
Towards CRISP-ML(Q): A Machine Learning Process Model with Quality
  Assurance Methodology
chunk_text:
The sixth phase covers state-of-the-art approaches for monitoring
and maintenance of a machine learning applications, as the risk of model
degradation in a changing environment is eminent.

title:
Towards CRISP-ML(Q): A Machine Learning Process Model with Quality
  Assurance Methodology
chunk_text:
With each task of the
process, we propose quality assurance methodology that is suitable to adress
challenges in machine learning development that we identify in form of risks.

title:
Towards CRISP-ML(Q): A Machine Learning Process Model with Quality
  Assurance Methodology
chunk_text:
The methodology is drawn from practical experience and scientific literature
and has proven to be general and stable.

title:
Towards CRISP-ML(Q): A Machine Learning Process Model with Quality
  Assurance Methodology
chunk_text:
The process model expands on CRISP-DM,
a data mining process model that enjoys strong industry support but lacks to
address machine learning specific tasks.

title:
Towards CRISP-ML(Q): A Machine Learning Process Model with Quality
  Assurance Methodology
chunk_text:
Our work proposes an industry and
application neutral process model tailored for machine learning applications
with focus on technical tasks for quality assurance.

title:
Temporal-related Convolutional-Restricted-Boltzmann-Machine capable of
  learning relational order via reinforcement learning procedure?
chunk_text:
In this article, we extend the conventional framework of
convolutional-Restricted-Boltzmann-Machine to learn highly abstract features
among abitrary number of time related input maps by constructing a layer of
multiplicative units, which capture the relations among inputs.

title:
Temporal-related Convolutional-Restricted-Boltzmann-Machine capable of
  learning relational order via reinforcement learning procedure?
chunk_text:
In many cases,
more than two maps are strongly related, so it is wise to make multiplicative
unit learn relations among more input maps, in other words, to find the optimal
relational-order of each unit.

title:
Temporal-related Convolutional-Restricted-Boltzmann-Machine capable of
  learning relational order via reinforcement learning procedure?
chunk_text:
In order to enable our machine to learn
relational order, we developed a reinforcement-learning method whose optimality
is proven to train the network.

title: Spatial Transfer Learning with Simple MLP
chunk_text:
First step to investigate the potential of transfer learning applied to the
field of spatial statistics

title:
Proceedings of the 29th International Conference on Machine Learning
  (ICML-12)
chunk_text:
This is an index to the papers that appear in the Proceedings of the 29th
International Conference on Machine Learning (ICML-12).

title:
Proceedings of the 29th International Conference on Machine Learning
  (ICML-12)
chunk_text:
The conference was held
in Edinburgh, Scotland, June 27th - July 3rd, 2012.

title: Distributed Multi-Task Learning with Shared Representation
chunk_text:
We study the problem of distributed multi-task learning with shared
representation, where each machine aims to learn a separate, but related, task
in an unknown shared low-dimensional subspaces, i.e.

title: Distributed Multi-Task Learning with Shared Representation
chunk_text:
when the predictor matrix
has low rank.

title: Distributed Multi-Task Learning with Shared Representation
chunk_text:
We consider a setting where each task is handled by a different
machine, with samples for the task available locally on the machine, and study
communication-efficient methods for exploiting the shared structure.

title: Components of Machine Learning: Binding Bits and FLOPS
chunk_text:
Many machine learning problems and methods are combinations of three
components: data, hypothesis space and loss function.

title: Components of Machine Learning: Binding Bits and FLOPS
chunk_text:
Different machine
learning methods are obtained as combinations of different choices for the
representation of data, hypothesis space and loss function.

title: Components of Machine Learning: Binding Bits and FLOPS
chunk_text:
After reviewing the
mathematical structure of these three components, we discuss intrinsic
trade-offs between statistical and computational properties of machine learning
methods.

title: Impact of Legal Requirements on Explainability in Machine Learning
chunk_text:
The requirements on explainability imposed by European laws and their
implications for machine learning (ML) models are not always clear.

title: Impact of Legal Requirements on Explainability in Machine Learning
chunk_text:
In that
perspective, our research analyzes explanation obligations imposed for private
and public decision-making, and how they can be implemented by machine learning
techniques.

title: Machine Learning Potential Repository
chunk_text:
This paper introduces a machine learning potential repository that includes
Pareto optimal machine learning potentials.

title: Machine Learning Potential Repository
chunk_text:
It also shows the systematic
development of accurate and fast machine learning potentials for a wide range
of elemental systems.

title: Machine Learning Potential Repository
chunk_text:
As a result, many Pareto optimal machine learning
potentials are available in the repository from a website.

title: Machine Learning Potential Repository
chunk_text:
Therefore, the
repository will help many scientists to perform accurate and fast atomistic
simulations.

title: Quantum memristors for neuromorphic quantum machine learning
chunk_text:
Quantum machine learning may permit to realize more efficient machine
learning calculations with near-term quantum devices.

title: Quantum memristors for neuromorphic quantum machine learning
chunk_text:
Among the diverse quantum
machine learning paradigms which are currently being considered, quantum
memristors are promising as a way of combining, in the same quantum hardware, a
unitary evolution with the nonlinearity provided by the measurement and
feedforward.

title: Quantum memristors for neuromorphic quantum machine learning
chunk_text:
Thus, an efficient way of deploying neuromorphic quantum computing
for quantum machine learning may be enabled.

title: metric-learn: Metric Learning Algorithms in Python
chunk_text:
metric-learn is an open source Python package implementing supervised and
weakly-supervised distance metric learning algorithms.

title: metric-learn: Metric Learning Algorithms in Python
chunk_text:
As part of
scikit-learn-contrib, it provides a unified interface compatible with
scikit-learn which allows to easily perform cross-validation, model selection,
and pipelining with other machine learning estimators.

title: metric-learn: Metric Learning Algorithms in Python
chunk_text:
metric-learn is
thoroughly tested and available on PyPi under the MIT licence.

title: Theoretical Models of Learning to Learn
chunk_text:
A Machine can only learn if it is biased in some way. Typically the bias is
supplied by hand, for example through the choice of an appropriate set of
features.

title: Theoretical Models of Learning to Learn
chunk_text:
However, if the learning machine is embedded within an {\em
environment} of related tasks, then it can {\em learn} its own bias by learning
sufficiently many tasks from the environment.

title: Theoretical Models of Learning to Learn
chunk_text:
In this paper two models of bias
learning (or equivalently, learning to learn) are introduced and the main
theoretical results presented.

title: Theoretical Models of Learning to Learn
chunk_text:
The first model is a PAC-type model based on
empirical process theory, while the second is a hierarchical Bayes model.

title:
An Aggregate and Iterative Disaggregate Algorithm with Proven Optimality
  in Machine Learning
chunk_text:
We propose a clustering-based iterative algorithm to solve certain
optimization problems in machine learning, where we start the algorithm by
aggregating the original data, solving the problem on aggregated data, and then
in subsequent steps gradually disaggregate the aggregated data.

title:
An Aggregate and Iterative Disaggregate Algorithm with Proven Optimality
  in Machine Learning
chunk_text:
We apply the
algorithm to common machine learning problems such as the least absolute
deviation regression problem, support vector machines, and semi-supervised
support vector machines.

title:
An Aggregate and Iterative Disaggregate Algorithm with Proven Optimality
  in Machine Learning
chunk_text:
We derive model-specific data aggregation and
disaggregation procedures. We also show optimality, convergence, and the
optimality gap of the approximated solution in each iteration.

title:
An Aggregate and Iterative Disaggregate Algorithm with Proven Optimality
  in Machine Learning
chunk_text:
A computational
study is provided.

title: Human-in-the-loop Machine Learning: A Macro-Micro Perspective
chunk_text:
Though technical advance of artificial intelligence and machine learning has
enabled many promising intelligent systems, many computing tasks are still not
able to be fully accomplished by machine intelligence.

title: Human-in-the-loop Machine Learning: A Macro-Micro Perspective
chunk_text:
Motivated by the
complementary nature of human and machine intelligence, an emerging trend is to
involve humans in the loop of machine learning and decision-making.

title: Human-in-the-loop Machine Learning: A Macro-Micro Perspective
chunk_text:
In this
paper, we provide a macro-micro review of human-in-the-loop machine learning. We first describe major machine learning challenges which can be addressed by
human intervention in the loop.

title: Human-in-the-loop Machine Learning: A Macro-Micro Perspective
chunk_text:
Then we examine closely the latest research and
findings of introducing humans into each step of the lifecycle of machine
learning.

title: Human-in-the-loop Machine Learning: A Macro-Micro Perspective
chunk_text:
Finally, we analyze current research gaps and point out future
research directions.

title: Can Machines Learn the True Probabilities?
chunk_text:
When there exists uncertainty, AI machines are designed to make decisions so
as to reach the best expected outcomes.

title: Can Machines Learn the True Probabilities?
chunk_text:
Expectations are based on true facts
about the objective environment the machines interact with, and those facts can
be encoded into AI models in the form of true objective probability functions.

title: Can Machines Learn the True Probabilities?
chunk_text:
Accordingly, AI models involve probabilistic machine learning in which the
probabilities should be objectively interpreted.

title: Can Machines Learn the True Probabilities?
chunk_text:
We prove under some basic
assumptions when machines can learn the true objective probabilities, if any,
and when machines cannot learn them.

title: On-the-Fly Learning in a Perpetual Learning Machine
chunk_text:
Despite the promise of brain-inspired machine learning, deep neural networks
(DNN) have frustratingly failed to bridge the deceptively large gap between
learning and memory.

title: On-the-Fly Learning in a Perpetual Learning Machine
chunk_text:
Here, we introduce a Perpetual Learning Machine; a new
type of DNN that is capable of brain-like dynamic 'on the fly' learning because
it exists in a self-supervised state of Perpetual Stochastic Gradient Descent.

title: On-the-Fly Learning in a Perpetual Learning Machine
chunk_text:
Thus, we provide the means to unify learning and memory within a machine
learning framework. We also explore the elegant duality of abstraction and
synthesis: the Yin and Yang of deep learning.

title: Scientific Machine Learning Benchmarks
chunk_text:
The breakthrough in Deep Learning neural networks has transformed the use of
AI and machine learning technologies for the analysis of very large
experimental datasets.

title: Scientific Machine Learning Benchmarks
chunk_text:
These datasets are typically generated by large-scale
experimental facilities at national laboratories.

title: Scientific Machine Learning Benchmarks
chunk_text:
In the context of science,
scientific machine learning focuses on training machines to identify patterns,
trends, and anomalies to extract meaningful scientific insights from such
datasets.

title: Scientific Machine Learning Benchmarks
chunk_text:
With a new generation of experimental facilities, the rate of data
generation and the scale of data volumes will increasingly require the use of
more automated data analysis.

title: Scientific Machine Learning Benchmarks
chunk_text:
At present, identifying the most appropriate
machine learning algorithm for the analysis of any given scientific dataset is
still a challenge for scientists.

title: Scientific Machine Learning Benchmarks
chunk_text:
This is due to many different machine
learning frameworks, computer architectures, and machine learning models.

title: Scientific Machine Learning Benchmarks
chunk_text:
Historically, for modelling and simulation on HPC systems such problems have
been addressed through benchmarking computer applications, algorithms, and
architectures.

title: Scientific Machine Learning Benchmarks
chunk_text:
Extending such a benchmarking approach and identifying metrics
for the application of machine learning methods to scientific datasets is a new
challenge for both scientists and computer scientists.

title: Scientific Machine Learning Benchmarks
chunk_text:
In this paper, we
describe our approach to the development of scientific machine learning
benchmarks and review other approaches to benchmarking scientific machine
learning.

title: Some Insights into Lifelong Reinforcement Learning Systems
chunk_text:
A lifelong reinforcement learning system is a learning system that has the
ability to learn through trail-and-error interaction with the environment over
its lifetime.

title: Some Insights into Lifelong Reinforcement Learning Systems
chunk_text:
In this paper, I give some arguments to show that the traditional
reinforcement learning paradigm fails to model this type of learning system.

title: Some Insights into Lifelong Reinforcement Learning Systems
chunk_text:
Some insights into lifelong reinforcement learning are provided, along with a
simplistic prototype lifelong reinforcement learning system.

title: Bayesian Optimization for Machine Learning : A Practical Guidebook
chunk_text:
The engineering of machine learning systems is still a nascent field; relying
on a seemingly daunting collection of quickly evolving tools and best
practices.

title: Bayesian Optimization for Machine Learning : A Practical Guidebook
chunk_text:
It is our hope that this guidebook will serve as a useful resource
for machine learning practitioners looking to take advantage of Bayesian
optimization techniques.

title: Bayesian Optimization for Machine Learning : A Practical Guidebook
chunk_text:
We outline four example machine learning problems that
can be solved using open source machine learning libraries, and highlight the
benefits of using Bayesian optimization in the context of these common machine
learning applications.

title: Towards A Rigorous Science of Interpretable Machine Learning
chunk_text:
As machine learning systems become ubiquitous, there has been a surge of
interest in interpretable machine learning: systems that provide explanation
for their outputs.

title: Towards A Rigorous Science of Interpretable Machine Learning
chunk_text:
These explanations are often used to qualitatively assess
other criteria such as safety or non-discrimination.

title: Towards A Rigorous Science of Interpretable Machine Learning
chunk_text:
However, despite the
interest in interpretability, there is very little consensus on what
interpretable machine learning is and how it should be measured.

title: Towards A Rigorous Science of Interpretable Machine Learning
chunk_text:
In this
position paper, we first define interpretability and describe when
interpretability is needed (and when it is not).

title: Towards A Rigorous Science of Interpretable Machine Learning
chunk_text:
Next, we suggest a taxonomy
for rigorous evaluation and expose open questions towards a more rigorous
science of interpretable machine learning.

title: Solving machine learning optimization problems using quantum computers
chunk_text:
Classical optimization algorithms in machine learning often take a long time
to compute when applied to a multi-dimensional problem and require a huge
amount of CPU and GPU resource.

title: Solving machine learning optimization problems using quantum computers
chunk_text:
Quantum parallelism has a potential to speed up
machine learning algorithms. We describe a generic mathematical model to
leverage quantum parallelism to speed-up machine learning algorithms.

title: Solving machine learning optimization problems using quantum computers
chunk_text:
We also
apply quantum machine learning and quantum parallelism applied to a
$3$-dimensional image that vary with time.

title: Infrastructure for Usable Machine Learning: The Stanford DAWN Project
chunk_text:
Despite incredible recent advances in machine learning, building machine
learning applications remains prohibitively time-consuming and expensive for
all but the best-trained, best-funded engineering organizations.

title: Infrastructure for Usable Machine Learning: The Stanford DAWN Project
chunk_text:
This expense
comes not from a need for new and improved statistical models but instead from
a lack of systems and tools for supporting end-to-end machine learning
application development, from data preparation and labeling to
productionization and monitoring.

title: Infrastructure for Usable Machine Learning: The Stanford DAWN Project
chunk_text:
In this document, we outline opportunities
for infrastructure supporting usable, end-to-end machine learning applications
in the context of the nascent DAWN (Data Analytics for What's Next) project at
Stanford.
